title: Getting a job - hv3
description: Deze les valt onder de arrangeerbare leerlijn van de Stercollectie voor Engels voor havo en vwo, leerjaar 3. Dit is thema 5 'Employment'. Het onderwerp van deze les is: Getting a job. In deze les staan aspecten van het krijgen van een baan centraal, zoals advertenties, het sollicitatiegesprek, belangrijke eigenschappen en vaardigheden. De onregelmatige werkwoorden in deze les zijn: to see, to seek, en to sell. In de grammaticaopdracht worden modale werkwoorden behandeld.

items.content:
The subject of this double period is getting hired.

  • Form groups of three or four pupils.

Discuss the following question in your group:
Imagine your friend is looking for a job and he or she doesn't know where to start.

  • Think of a top 5 of things your friend might do to find a job.

Step

activity

aim

time

introduction

Find out what you already know.

10

Step 1

listening
Looking for a job

You can understand a video about how to find a job and answer questions about it.

15

Step 2

reading
Getting hired

You can understand a text about getting hired and answer questions about it.

15

Step 3

vocabulary and irregular verbs

You can understand and use vocabulary about work. The irregular verbs: to see, to seek and to sell.

15

Step 4

grammar
Modal verbs

You can understand and use modal verbs.

10

Step 5

speaking
Talking about jobs part 2

You can have a discussion about work.

10

Step 6

writing
Application letter nurse

You can write an application letter in English.

20

Step 7

evaluation

Reflecting on what you have learnt.

5

Looking for a job

You are going to watch a video of Graham Martin who works at a recruitment agency.

  • Watch the video and do assignment 1.
  • Read the questions.
  • Watch the video again and do assignment 2.

Assignment 1

Watch the video and answer the question on your own, then discuss the answer in your group.

  • What tips does Graham give to find work?

prompt.body:
• On your own, answer the 10 questions.
  • Compare your answers in your group.

Questions

  1. What is Graham's nickname?
  2. How did Graham first want to share his knowledge?
  3. Why is it difficult to find a job?
  4. What does Graham say about the number of jobs?
  5. How could you find a job in the past?
  6. What is looking for a job like nowadays?
  7. Why should you go to a local recruitment agency?
  8. What does he say about the job centre?
  9. Why should you look at the website of the company you would like to work for?
  10. What warning does he give about social media?

values.value:
1. The recruitment guy.
  2. He tried to write a book on the subject.
  3. The employees and employers are not in contact with each other.
  4. They are increasing.
  5. Send a couple of letters.
  6. It is like a day time job.
  7. They know what jobs are available in your area.
  8. Don’t ignore them, most of them want to help people to find a job.
  9. With the information from the site you can contact them yourself.
  10. Employers often look at social media sites, so be careful what you post.

content.body:
1. The recruitment guy.
  2. He tried to write a book on the subject.
  3. The employees and employers are not in contact with each other.
  4. They are increasing.
  5. Send a couple of letters.
  6. It is like a day time job.
  7. They know what jobs are available in your area.
  8. Don't ignore them, most of them want to help people to find a job.
  9. With the information from the site you can contact them yourself.
  10. Employers often look at social media sites, so be careful what you post.

items.content:
Eight traits that will boost your chances of getting hired

You are going to read a text about enhancing your chances of being hired.

  • Read the text (in sections) and answer the questions.

header.title: Eight traits that will boost your chances of getting hired

prompt.body:
By Jane Bianchi
(This post originally appeared on LearnVest)

Why is it that some people just seem to effortlessly climb the career ladder? You know these folks we speak of: They always know how to dazzle during an interview, and they have a knack for nabbing that prime position before it's even posted.

What's their secret?
According to the authors of "Fearless Job Hunting: Powerful Psychological Strategies for Getting the Job You Want," these are people who have mastered the job hunt by not only honing their skills but also building up the psychological know-how to get through a sometimes soul-crushing process. We tapped two of the book's co-authors-Bill Knaus, a psychologist who specializes in personnel selection, and Russell Grieger, a psychologist and organizational consultant-to find out what makes such so-called fearless job hunters tick. Based on their research, Knaus and Grieger have pinpointed eight key traits that they say make these job-seekers so resilient-and a hiring manager's dream.

English Dutch
the trait de eigenschap
effortlessly moeiteloos
to dazzle imponeren
the interview het sollicitatiegesprek
to hone slijpen, verfijnen
to have a knack het foefje kennen
to nab aan de haak slaan
to post publiceren, bekendmaken
to tap aankloppen bij
the consultant de adviseur
what makes you tick wat jou/u drijft


Question
People who get all the jobs:

content.body: keep refining their abilities and learn about how the mind works.
keep refining their abilities and know how the mind works.
have refined abilities and learn about how the mind works.
have refined abilities and know how the mind works.

prompt.body:
1. They Accentuate the Positives
It's easy to feel down on yourself after getting rejected for a dream job, either telling yourself that you're a failure or that you don't have what it takes to succeed.
According to Grieger, that's because "so many people wrap their self-worth around their careers." There are, however, ways to dig yourself out of that hole of negativity, and approach the process in a more fearless fashion. First, ask yourself whether what you're thinking is logical-and whether it gets you anywhere.
Here's a hint: The answer to both should be no! Then flip the script, and tell yourself, "This will be hard, but I can do it," or "I've accomplished a lot in my life, and I'm fully capable of accomplishing this."
Even if your career prospects don't pan out, don't accept that as the be-all, end-all. Instead, say to yourself, "If I fail at this, it doesn't mean that my whole life is a failure," or "I have a lot to offer - if this interviewer doesn't appreciate it, someone else will." Finally, give yourself a pep talk by writing down a list of your best qualities as a person, as well as an employee, and then read them aloud. This will help to build up your confidence - and further motivate you during the job hunt.

English Dutch
to accentuate benadrukken
to reject afwijzen
according to volgens
to approach benaderen
whether of (als in: Ik weet niet of ze komt.)
to flip op zijn kop zetten
to accomplish volbrengen, bereiken
to pan out er rooskleurig uitzien
to appreciate op zijn waarde schatten
the confidence het zelfvertrouwen


Question
Who should be convinced of your abilities, according to the text?

2. They Identify Their Hang-Ups
Does job hunting stress you out so much that you keep putting it off? Once you can confront your specific issues head on, you'll put less stress on yourself - fearless job hunter-style.
Start by pinpointing what could be the underlying cause (or causes) of your particular hang-up, and then "strip away whatever loadstone you have on your back," says Knaus.
For instance, if you're nervous that your résumé isn't up to par, ask a mentor to critique it.
Or if you're unsure of what to say in an interview, practice with a friend and videotape the session, so you can review it and improve upon your delivery.

English Dutch
to stress out nerveus maken
to put off uitstellen
the issue het punt, het probleem
to pinpoint vaststellen
the hang-up het psychische of emotionele probleem
to have a loadstone on your back een gewicht met je meetorsen
not up to par ondermaats
the delivery de prestatie


Question
Successful applicants .................

content.body: must know their weaknesses and prepare well.
must know their weaknesses and videotape their interview.
must have a perfect résumé and prepare well.
must have a perfect résumé and videotape their interview.

prompt.body:
3. They Have Passion - and Purpose
There are a lot of different ways to think about work. For some people, it's simply a way to put bread on the table.
But fearless job hunters view their 9-to-5 as an expression of their purpose in life. If you've never gotten this existential about your career before, here's a good place to start. Ask yourself what you believe is the real reason for being on this Earth - and what sort of job can help you achieve that goal.
Grieger, for example, tells himself that he's here "to help people have happy and prosperous lives," which, in turn, fuels his passion for being a psychologist. When you think about your career in this way, says Grieger, the job search becomes less of a drag and more of an exciting and profoundly satisfying experience.
The hunt will no longer be a chore to postpone, but rather an opportunity that you can't wait to take advantage of.
Plus, you'll optimize your search by focusing solely on positions that can help you express your purpose.

English Dutch
to achieve a goal een doel bereiken
prosperous voorspoedig
to fuel aanwakkeren
the drag iets om tegen op te zien
to take advantage of profiteren van
solely uitsluitend


Question
Successful applicants .............

content.body: should take advantage of the interviewer.
should know what really drives them.
should behave exited during the interview.

prompt.body:
4. They "Pressure-Proof" Themselves
Successful job seekers are patient, persistent and, most important, resilient.
"They see the job hunt as a process, not an event," says Knaus, adding that they exhibit what Grieger calls "high frustration tolerance."
Did bumper-to-bumper traffic make you late for an interview? Or did you spill coffee on your newly pressed button-down right before you met with a recruiter? These types of scenarios are less likely to derail the confidence of a fearless job hunter because they accept - and expect - setbacks.
Bottom line, says Grieger, is to acknowledge that you'll make mistakes along the way, and sometimes encounter circumstances that are out of your control.
"Don't expect perfection from yourself," he says. "Do the best you can."

English Dutch
persistent volhardend
resilient flexibel
to exhibit vertonen
the tolerance verdraagzaamheid
button-down (shirt) overhemd met knoopjes aan de kraag
to derail van streek maken
the setback de tegenslag
bottom line waar het op neerkomt
to acknowledge erkennen
to encounter tegenkomen


Question
Successful applicants ....................

5. They Network, Network, Network
"Networking is the most important thing that you can do," says Knaus. "And it's the biggest return for your time."
So think about who you know who might be able to give you the inside information on a job opening.
When you're assertive and proactive, opportunities are more likely to come your way.
This is not a time to be shy - put yourself out there.

English Dutch
the return de opbrengst
the job opening de vacature
proactive anticiperend
the opportunity de kans
shy verlegen
to put yourself out je uitsloven


Question
Successful applicants enhance their chances by ............

content.body: inside information and a job opening.
returning chances and connecting to people.
inside information and connecting to people.
returning chances and a job opening.

prompt.body:
6. They Always Do Their Homework
When you're getting ready for an interview, the more background information you have, the less anxious you'll feel.
And we're not just talking about checking out your hiring manager's LinkedIn profile. Instead, look into the actual business.
"Use the Internet to make sure that you have knowledge of the organization," says Knaus. "Write down a few questions to ask the interviewer. And find out the company's main problems."
A good place to ferret this out is by reading customer complaints online. "Then suggest ways that you can help solve those problems," adds Knaus. "Or ways that you can add value to the company with your particular skills."

English Dutch
anxious nerveus
instead in plaats (daar)van
main voornaamst(e)
the ferret de fret (dier)
to ferret out uitvissen
customer complaints klachten van klanten, de klachtenafdeling
particular uniek(e)
the skill de vaardigheid


Question
Below, you will find four sets of advices. One of those sets contains an advice that is not in the paragraph. Which one?

content.body: Find out how the company is organized; find out their major issues; ask questions to the interviewer.
Suggest how you might help them; point out what added value you have; find out their major issues.
Find out how the company is organized; submit a complaint in the complaint department; ask the interviewer some questions.
Suggest how you might help them; find out their major issues; ask questions to the interviewer.

prompt.body:
7. They Concey Confidence
Yes, you want to tout your skills and achievements, but your approach can mean the difference between coming across as likable or unhearable.
So choose your words wisely, and own the motto "show, don't tell," suggests Knaus.
So rather than saying, "I'm amazing at increasing profits," use facts to back it up by saying, "Last year I was the leader of a team that boosted profits 40%." And build a rapport with an interviewer by finding common ground before you make it all about you. "If you see that the person has a photo of airplanes on the wall, you might ask, 'Do you fly?' he says. "Show interest and see if you can get a conversation going."

English Dutch
to tout hier: voor het voetlicht brengen
to back up ondersteunen
to boost verhogen


Question
What are two structural problems of this paragraph?

content.body: It covers one subject instead of two, yet the extra space between the lines suggests two subjects.
There are too many quotation marks for so small a text and one should never start a sentence with 'so'.
Not all quotes have quotation marks and the spacing is confusing.
It covers two subjects instead of one and the second subject is not indicated with an extra space between the lines.

prompt.body:
8. They Learn From Each Let-down

In the job hunt, no one is ever going to bat a thousand. If you didn't get the position that you were positive you were a frontrunner for, assess what might have gone wrong - and see what you can change for the future.
"After you leave an interview, you often have 'woulda, coulda, shoulda's' - things you know you could have done better," Knaus says. "Look back and recalculate, based on what you learned. See if there are patterns and trends."
Maybe you forgot to prepare questions, or you were under- or overqualified for the gig. Perhaps you got nervous and didn't sell yourself as well as you could have, or didn't know how to properly explain a career gap on your résumé. If you can identify your weaknesses, you can improve on them - and turn them into strengths for the next round.

English Dutch
the let-down de tegenslag
to bat a thousand meteen de hoofdprijs winnen
the gig de klus
the career gap on your résumé het gat in je CV


Question
The applicant that was not hired should ..................

content.body: reflect on the way they operated.
turn their let downs into performance.

In twee keer 10 minuten leer je meer dan in een half uur.

Irregular Verbs

Bekijk de onderstaande kennisbank en bestudeer de volgende irregular verbs (onregelmatige werkwoorden):

  • to see
  • to seek
  • to sell

items.content:
Modal verbs

  • Study the theory.
  • Do assignment 1.
Modals of necessity

prompt.body:
Choose the correct answer for each sentence.

Mr. Wu: Hi, Mark. Where's your dad?

Mark: Oh, he ........................ to work because there was an emergency.

Choose the correct answer for each sentence.

When a police officer asks to see your driver's license, you .................................. to him/her.

Choose the correct answer for each sentence.

According to the law, drivers .......................... at stop signs.

Choose the correct answer for each sentence.

If you have a pet dog, you ................................ feed it every day or it will die!

Choose the correct answer for each sentence.

In order to log on to the Internet, Sally ........................ her user I.D.

Choose the correct answer for each sentence.

Son: Mom, I don't want to clean my room. ................................ it right now?

Mother: Yes, right now.

Choose the correct answer for each sentence.

If Richard wants to become a professional musician, he ........................... every day.

Choose the correct answer for each sentence.

Friend:....................................... pay to see the doctor?

Brother: No, she................................ because she has medical insurance.

content.body: Does your sister have to / doesn't
Do your sister have to / doesn't

items.content:
Talking about jobs part 2

Read the questions and decide which 5 you are going to discuss in your group.

  1. Do you have good employment prospects, or will you have, once you have left school?
  2. Do you ever look at the employment pages in newspapers? What other sources of information about positions can you think about?
  3. Do you think companies should offer employees lifetime employment? Why?
  4. Are there any conditions of employment you insist on? If so, what are these?
  5. Are there equal opportunities in employment in your country? Theoretically and practically? Consider sex, gender, skin, origins, etc.
  6. Would you like to be self-employed? Why do you or don't you?
  7. Do you think young people care enough about their employment prospects? Do you?
  8. What rules should there be regarding children and employment?
  9. Which countries and companies do you think offer the best employment opportunities? What makes you think so?
  10. What help should a government give those looking for employment? Why?

Application letter nurse

You are going to write an application letter.

  • Read the advertisement (from monsterboard.com).
  • Write the letter (on your own).
  • Form groups of three or four pupils.
  • Read and discuss your work.
  • Help each other and correct mistakes.
  • Hand in the final letter to your teacher.

Read the advertisement.

Job Summary

Company peopleCare - Oakcrossing London
Location London, ON N6H0G2
Industries Healthcare Services
Job Type Full Time
Employee
Career Level Entry Level
Job Reference Code 28749

Registered Nurse - About the Job
peopleCare is one of Ontario's leading - owner / managers of Long-Term Care Communities, with properties located in Cambridge, London, Stratford, Tavistock, Delhi and Kitchener.

peopleCare has been recognized as Canada's 50 Most Engaged Employers, granted 'Exemplary Standing' by Accreditation Canada and earned 'Best Practice Spotlight Organization' candidacy by the Registered Nurses' Association of Ontario.

As a member of the peopleCare nursing team, this position provides for all aspects of nursing care and directs the work of nursing and personal care staff in the assigned unit. In performing these duties, the individual may assume the duties of charge nurse in an assigned unit. The position ensures all legislative standards, company policies and procedures and rule and regulations are adhered to in a professional manner. Full and Part time positions available.

Reports to: Director of Care/Director of Nursing or Director of Clinical Care
